channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Deal to Bring Supplies to Syrian Town Mired in Distrust
item.description: Government officials and rebels blame one another as no aid is yet delivered to the the 8,000 civilians in Moadhamiya, just outside the city limits of Damascus.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Turkish Leader Denounces Graft Investigation
item.description: A day after three cabinet ministers resigned, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the premier, said those who tried to embroil him in the inquiry would be “left empty-handed.”
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Turkish protesters in Istanbul on Wednesday shouted slogans as they held signs calling for the government’s resignation.

item.title: India Opposition Leader Will Not Be Charged Over Riots
item.description: A court declined to prosecute Narendra Modi for his role in the Gujarat riots, although the government is now investigating him in an unrelated case.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Thai Election Body Urges Delay in Polls Amid Violence
item.description: A deputy prime minister rejected the proposal, saying that the government has no power to postpone elections and that a delay could lead to “prolonged violence.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters outside Bangkok's Thai-Japanese Stadium hurl rocks at riot policemen.

item.title: India Ink: Bad Scripts and Politics Make for a Bad Year in Tollywood
item.description: The Telugu-language film industry is facing its worst financial slump in a decade.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: N.T. Rama Rao, a Telugu language film star and former chief minister of Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: Letter from Washington: Appointing Political Friends to Be Ambassadors
item.description: In few democracies could someone go from political fund-raiser and media honcho to ambassador to assistant secretary of state, as Charles Rivkin might.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: American Held by Al Qaeda in Pakistan Asks Obama to Negotiate Release
item.description: In a video message, Warren Weinstein, who was abducted in 2011, said that the United States had abandoned and forgotten him.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 26
item.description: Women in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, commemorating the ninth anniversary of a tsunami that killed more than 200,000 people in Asia.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Blast Injures at Least 5 on Cairo Bus
item.description: An explosive device was detonated in the middle of a busy street in the Egyptian capital on Thursday, injuring at least five passengers on a nearby public bus.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Japanese Premier Visits Contentious War Shrine
item.description: The visit by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Thursday revived a practice that has long strained relations between Japan and its Asian neighbors.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, center, was the first Japanese prime minister since 2006 to visit a shrine in Tokyo honoring the country’s war dead.

item.title: African Leaders Seek to End South Sudan Violence
item.description: The president of Kenya and the prime minister of Ethiopia arrived Thursday in South Sudan for talks with President Salva Kiir on how to find a solution to the fighting that has engulfed the young nation.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: South Sudanese soldiers on Wednesday in Bor, which the army retook after it fell to rebels. Violence continues to grip the country.

item.title: Japanese Premier Visits Contentious War Shrine
item.description: The visit by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to the Yasukuni Shrine revived a practice that has long strained relations between Japan and its Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, center, was the first Japanese prime minister since 2006 to visit a shrine in Tokyo honoring the country’s war dead.

item.title: Mantecal Journal: Venezuela’s Fitful Effort to Save a Scaly Predator
item.description: A ranch that was expropriated by Venezuela’s government in 2009 represents both the hopes and the frustrations of conservationists who have worked to save the Orinoco crocodile.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and PAULA RAMÓN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Álvaro Velasco, a specialist, at a government-run ranch in Venezuela that breeds the Orinoco crocodile.

item.title: U.S. Sends Arms to Aid Iraq Fight With Extremists
item.description: After an appeal for help, the United States is rushing dozens of missiles and surveillance drones to help Iraqi forces combat violence by a Qaeda-backed insurgency.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Iraqis gathered in Tikrit on Tuesday to pray over journalists killed in an attack claimed by a Qaeda-affiliated group.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Liu Ping’s Christmas in Jail
item.description: For Liu Ping, a Christian, and one of three campaigners for democracy and public disclosure of leaders’ assets detained and tried on charges their supporters say are false, this Christmas is very different.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Gillles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Ping is awaiting sentencing on charges related to her campaign for Chinese leaders to disclose their assets.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Turks and Caicos Islands: 18 Believed to Be Migrants From Haiti Drown
item.description: Eighteen people believed to be migrants from Haiti died Wednesday when their overloaded sailboat overturned as it was being escorted to shore in the Turks and Caicos Islands.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Building Plans for Settlements
item.description: Israel is likely to announce new plans for construction in Jewish settlements next week, a move that is likely to set off an international uproar and threaten peace talks with the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Chile: Indian Leader Found in Reservoir
item.description: Nicolesa Quintreman, the face of Chile’s environmental movement, was found dead, floating in a reservoir she tried to prevent from being created, and the authorities said that they were awaiting autopsy results.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Leader Seeks to Slow Protests
item.description: The Thai prime minister on Wednesday proposed the formation of a reform council to mollify a protest movement seeking to topple her government, but her opponents immediately rejected her idea.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Bill to Raise Uranium Enrichment
item.description: Iranian lawmakers introduced a bill in Parliament that would force the government to increase uranium enrichment to 60 percent if new sanctions are imposed on Iran.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: South Sudan’s President Condemns Ethnic Killings
item.description: President Salva Kiir gave a Christmas address amid heavy fighting that has killed or displaced thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: About 12,000 members of the Nuer ethnic group in South Sudan have fled to a United Nations camp near the Juba airport.

item.title: Russia Clears Most Activists in Oil Protest
item.description: Charges against all but one of the 30 crew members of a Greenpeace ship, who protested at a Russian oil rig, were dropped.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Scotland Struggles to Keep an Energy Lifeline
item.description: The petrochemical complex at Grangemouth has become a shimmering symbol of Scotland at an economic and political crossroads.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Robert Ormerod for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grangemouth is a close-knit, densely settled urban area of about 17,000 people whose roots in the chemical and oil industries go back more than a century to the glory days of British industry.

item.title: Start-Up Spirit Emerges in Japan
item.description: While prejudice against entrepreneurs lingers in Japan, the nation is increasingly trying to encourage business start-ups as a key to the future.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Corruption Scandal Is Edging Near Turkish Premier
item.description: A corruption inquiry took an ominous step closer to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan as three cabinet ministers resigned, with one calling for him to step down as well.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Turkish protesters in Istanbul on Wednesday shouted slogans as they held signs calling for the government’s resignation.
